Bill de Blasio has a history of indecisiveness...going back to his work on the Hillary Clinton campaign - from which he was ultimately removed...

'In 2000, a War Room Didn’t Fit de Blasio’s Style'

"In the middle of the 2000 Senate race, Hillary Rodham Clinton’s advisers found themselves on a conference call about what seemed a small-bore subject: campaign signs.

For 20 minutes it droned on. What color should their signs be for the Democratic National Convention that summer? And what about the font?

One person had the power to end the discussion — the campaign manager, Bill de Blasio. But he declined to intervene.

“Finally, someone said: ‘Seriously? Come on people, let’s go with blue!’ ” recalled a Clinton adviser, whose account was confirmed by two other people.

“It was amazing that Bill was more than willing to let this go on.”

[...]

An examination of Mr. de Blasio’s management of Mrs. Clinton’s first run for office, however, reveals that his inclinations — inclusive and easygoing but frequently indecisive — could be agonizingly inefficient in a high-pressure, ever-shifting situation. He was so deliberative, in fact, that he was eventually elbowed out during the final stretch of the campaign.

http://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/26/nyregion/in-2000-a-clinton-war-room-di...

Talking about the minimum wage in context of raising a family is entirely unreasonable. While raising the minimum wage to $10 or so will not raise costs considerably, supporting a spouse and 2 kids costs substantially more -- something closer to $25. And what of the family with 4 kids? That may take $40/hr. to support -- a good bit more than most people make. Should wages be completely turned on their head, with pay based on number of children and not education or productivity? Or should people be expected to use *gasp* personal responsibility and not have kids they can't support. And why can't parents utilize childcare or extended family to care for kids while they both work?
I personally think that some parents may have to have choices made for them regarding kids. For instance, if they can't get jobs, then the kids have to go to state-funded daycare while the parents get training or develop experience at an entry level job. Once they can support themselves and kids in a reasonable way, then they can make their own choices again.

I wonder whether sidewalks could instead be the factor on those days when it seems unnecessary to close school. In a city like Portland where a fair number of children actually walk to school, couldn't impassable sidewalks and/or intersections that are unsafe for pedestrians also lead to school closures? The surrounding suburbs wouldn't have this issue (sadly!), so it makes sense that those kids might sometimes be in school when Portland must call a snow day.

An 80 year old nutritional mystery has been solved in time to benefit the author's dentition. Dr. Weston A.Price was a dental surgeon who became frustrated with repair work when the cause went unaddressed. He roamed the world in the 1920s visiting isolated peoples still living on their native diets. Price determined that a factor existed in butter from pastured cows that protected teeth. In the 1920s analytical methods were inadequate to determine the chemical nature of this nutrient so Price called it Activator-X. Recently it has been determined that Price's food factor was Vitamin K2. This nutrient, with different sources and actions than Vitamin K1, has two major functions with regard to the metabolism of calcium in our bodies. [1] It directs calcium to teeth and bones where you want it. [2] It removes calcium from soft tissues like arteries, veins and aorta where you don't want it. Vitamin K2 activated matrix gla protein is the strongest inhibitor of tissue calcification presently known. Read Dr. Kate Rhéaume-Bleue's book Vitamin K2 and the Calcium Paradox

You blithely talk about marketing and public relations as all powerful. As a marketing professional, I agree provided you follow the only reality-based Austrian School. I refer to the late Professor Peter Drucker who defined marketing as “What do customers want and need - Not what do we have to sell.” As long as the Democrats focus on what Americans want and need, while the Republicans focus on what their plutocrat owners want them to sell, popular support for the Democrats will continue to grow.

Speaking of zombies and cockroaches, let us not ignore those who are forever invoking graphs, laws, equations, and data in a never ending attempt at converting conservative economists, despite all the evidence showing that graphs, laws, equations, and data have never had any appreciable effect on such people.

And for good reason: those economists know that public support for economic policy or anything else has never, does not, and will never depend on numbers. As such, they have a much deeper understanding of their professional prerogatives than their critics. Popular support is the name of the game, and greed, spite, and stupidity rule the public arena. Contempt for the poor sells tax cuts for the rich. Youth and sex appeal sell tobacco. Numbers are irrelevant.

All, however, is not lost. If artists and copywriters could persuade 25% of the population to addict themselves to a poison that would eventually kill them, they can persuade these same people to believe anything else. Cockroaches and zombies stand no chance against marketing and public relations.
